'''''Russula albidula''''' is a species of [[mushroom]] in the genus ''[[Russula]]''. The species, known in the [[common name|vernacular]] as the '''boring white russula''' or the '''whitish brittlegill''', is nondescript, with a small or medium dirty white fruit body, and a highly acrid taste. It is found in eastern North America.

== Taxonomy ==

The species was first described by the American mycologist [[Charles Horton Peck]] in 1898. Mycologist [[David Arora]], describing the fruit bodies as "plain, unprepossessing, [and] profoundly forgettable", calls the species the "boring white Russula".<ref name=Arora1986>{{cite book |author=Arora D. |title=Mushrooms Demystified: a Comprehensive Guide to the Fleshy Fungi |publisher=Ten Speed Press |location=Berkeley, Calif |year=1986 |page=96 |isbn=0-89815-169-4|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=86tM01VsFG0C&lpg=PA96&dq=Russula%20albidula&pg=PA96#v=onepage&q=Russula%20albidula&f=false|accessdate=2009-10-26}}</ref> Another [[common name]] is the "whitish brittlegill".<ref name=McKnight1987>{{cite book |vauthors=McKnight VB, McKnight KH |title=A Field Guide to Mushrooms, North America |publisher=Houghton Mifflin |location=Boston |year=1987 |page=317 |isbn=0-395-91090-0|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kSdA3V7Z9WcC&lpg=RA1-PA317&dq=Russula%20albidula&pg=RA1-PA317#v=onepage&q=Russula%20albidula&f=false|accessdate=2009-10-25}}</ref>

== Description ==

The [[pileus (mycology)|cap]] of the [[basidiocarp|fruit body]] is convex to almost flat, {{convert|2.5|to|10|cm|in|abbr=on|1}} broad, with a white surface that becomes yellowish when dry. The cap surface is viscid when moist, and have a [[pileipellis|cuticle]] that can be peeled off. The [[Lamella (mycology)|gills]] are white, equal, sometimes forking next to the stipe, and have an [[Adnation|adnate]] or slightly [[decurrent]] attachment to the stem. The [[stipe (mycology)|stipe]] is white, smooth, {{convert|2.5|to|6|cm|in|abbr=on|1}} long and {{convert|0.8|to|2|cm|in|abbr=on|1}} wide. The [[trama (mycology)|flesh]], which is fragile and white,<ref name=Miller2006/> has a very bitter taste.<ref name=Beardslee1914>{{cite journal |doi=10.2307/3753637 |author=Beardslee HC. |year=1914 |title=Notes on a few Asheville fungi |jstor=3753637 |journal=Mycologia |volume=6 |issue=3 |pages=88–92}}</ref> Specimens found in the field are typically dirty and dingy.<ref name=Arora1986/>

In [[spore print|deposit]], the [[basidiospore|spores]] are pale yellow. Viewed microscopically, they are roughly spherical, thin-walled, and have dimensions of 6–7.5 by 7.5–10 [[micrometre|µm]].<ref>{{cite book |author = Murrill WA. | year =1910 | title = North American Flora. Vol. 9| publisher =New York Botanical Press| isbn =|page= 216}}</ref> The surface of the spores is marked by broken [[wikt:reticulate|reticulations]].<ref name=Beardslee1914/>

===Edibility===
The highly acrid taste of ''Russula albidula'' is a deterrent to consumption,<ref name=Arora1986/> although it is not considered poisonous.<ref name=Miller2006>{{cite book |vauthors=Miller HR, Miller OK |title=North American Mushrooms: a Field Guide to Edible and Inedible Fungi |publisher=Falcon Guide |location=Guilford, Conn |year=2006 |page=77 |isbn=0-7627-3109-5|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zjvXkLpqsEgC&lpg=PA77&dq=Russula%20albidula&pg=PA77#v=onepage&q=Russula%20albidula&f=false |accessdate=2009-10-26}}</ref>

===Similar species===
Other ''Russula'' species that bear a resemblance to ''R. albidula'' include ''[[Russula albella|R. albella]]'', ''[[Russula albida|R. albida]]'', ''[[Russula anomala|R. anomala]]'', and ''[[Russula subalbidula|R. subalbidula]]''.<ref name=Arora1986/> It may also be confused with white waxycaps (genus ''[[Hygrophorus]]'') or ''[[Tricholoma]]'' species.<ref name=McKnight1987/>

==Habitat and distribution==
The fruit bodies of ''Russula albidula'' can be found growing solitary or grouped together on the ground in woods (both [[mixed forest|mixed]] and [[coniferous forest|coniferous]]) or the edges of woods; specimens are often found near [[oak]] trees.<ref name=Miller2006/> The species has a penchant for appearing in poor soil like that found on roadsides and along trails.<ref name=Arora1986/> ''Russula albidula'' is distributed in eastern North America.<ref name=Miller2006/>
